sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The View.WhatDotColor function is used to determine the color number of the specified pixel. The alternate spelling is View.WhatDotColour.
sections.text_content:
The View.WhatDotColor function is used to determine the color 
          number of the specified pixel. The alternate spelling is 
	  View.WhatDotColour.
sections.mdown_content: The **View.WhatDotColor** function is used to determine the color number of the specified pixel. The alternate spelling is **View.WhatDotColour**.

sections.title: Example
code:
View.Set ( "graphics" )
        var x, y : int := 0
        var dx, dx : int := 1
        loop
            if View.WhatDotColor ( x, y ) not= 0 and
	            View.WhatDotColor ( x, y ) not= brightred then
                Draw.FillOval (x, y, 10, 10, brightred)
            end if
            Draw.Dot ( x, y, 1 )
            x := x + dx
            y := y + dy
            if x = 0 or x = maxx then
                dx := -dx
            end if
            if y = 0 or y = maxy then
                dy := -dy
            end if
        end loop
sections.raw_content: This program draws a line which bounces off the edges of the screen and makes a beep when it finds a pixel that has already been colored.

sections.title: Example
sections.raw_content: Another example illustrates the use of View.WhatDotColor to determine the color of pixels in a window painted with multi-color blocks. The actual color number appears in the block. The color of the dot under the mouse cursor appears in the upper-left corner of the window. Note that you can also place the mouse cursor over the black text indicating the color number.
